00003| .. _cli:
00004| 
00005| Command Line Interface
00006| ======================
00007| 
00008| Installing Flask installs the ``flask`` script, a `Click`_ command line
00009| interface, in your virtualenv. Executed from the terminal, this script gives
00010| access to built-in, extension, and application-defined commands. The ``--help``
00011| option will give more information about any commands and options.
00012| 
00013| .. _Click: http://click.pocoo.org/
00014| 
00015| 
00016| Application Discovery
00017| ---------------------
00018| 
00019| The ``flask`` command is installed by Flask, not your application; it must be
00020| told where to find your application in order to use it. The ``FLASK_APP``
00021| environment variable is used to specify how to load the application.
00022| 
00023| Unix Bash (Linux, Mac, etc.)::
00024| 
00025|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello
00026|     $ flask run
00027| 
00028| Windows CMD::
00029| 
00030|     > set FLASK_APP=hello
00031|     > flask run
00032| 
00033| Windows PowerShell::
00034| 
00035|     > $env:FLASK_APP = "hello"
00036|     > flask run
00037| 
00038| While ``FLASK_APP`` supports a variety of options for specifying your
00039| application, most use cases should be simple. Here are the typical values:
00040| 
00041| (nothing)
00042|     The file :file:`wsgi.py` is imported, automatically detecting an app
00043|     (``app``). This provides an easy way to create an app from a factory with
00044|     extra arguments.
00045| 
00046| ``FLASK_APP=hello``
00047|     The name is imported, automatically detecting an app (``app``) or factory
00048|     (``create_app``).
00049| 
00050| ----
00051| 
00052| ``FLASK_APP`` has three parts: an optional path that sets the current working
00053| directory, a Python file or dotted import path, and an optional variable
00054| name of the instance or factory. If the name is a factory, it can optionally
00055| be followed by arguments in parentheses. The following values demonstrate these
00056| parts:
00057| 
00058| ``FLASK_APP=src/hello``
00059|     Sets the current working directory to ``src`` then imports ``hello``.
00060| 
00061| ``FLASK_APP=hello.web``
00062|     Imports the path ``hello.web``.
00063| 
00064| ``FLASK_APP=hello:app2``
00065|     Uses the ``app2`` Flask instance in ``hello``.
00066| 
00067| ``FLASK_APP="hello:create_app('dev')"``
00068|     The ``create_app`` factory in ``hello`` is called with the string ``'dev'``
00069|     as the argument.
00070| 
00071| If ``FLASK_APP`` is not set, the command will look for a file called
00072| :file:`wsgi.py` or :file:`app.py` and try to detect an application instance or
00073| factory.
00074| 
00075| Within the given import, the command looks for an application instance named
00076| ``app`` or ``application``, then any application instance. If no instance is
00077| found, the command looks for a factory function named ``create_app`` or
00078| ``make_app`` that returns an instance.
00079| 
00080| When calling an application factory, if the factory takes an argument named
00081| ``info``, then the :class:`~cli.ScriptInfo` instance is passed as a keyword
00082| argument. If parentheses follow the factory name, their contents are parsed
00083| as Python literals and passes as arguments to the function. This means that
00084| strings must still be in quotes.
00085| 
00086| 
00087| Run the Development Server
00088| --------------------------
00089| 
00090| The :func:`run <cli.run_command>` command will start the development server. It
00091| replaces the :meth:`Flask.run` method in most cases. ::
00092| 
00093|     $ flask run
00094|      * Serving Flask app "hello"
00095|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)
00096| 
00097| .. warning:: Do not use this command to run your application in production.
00098|     Only use the development server during development. The development server
00099|     is provided for convenience, but is not designed to be particularly secure,
00100|     stable, or efficient. See :ref:`deployment` for how to run in production.
00101| 
00102| 
00103| Open a Shell
00104| ------------
00105| 
00106| To explore the data in your application, you can start an interactive Python
00107| shell with the :func:`shell <cli.shell_command>` command. An application
00108| context will be active, and the app instance will be imported. ::
00109| 
00110|     $ flask shell
00111|     Python 3.6.2 (default, Jul 20 2017, 03:52:27)
00112|     [GCC 7.1.1 20170630] on linux
00113|     App: example
00114|     Instance: /home/user/Projects/hello/instance
00115|     >>>
00116| 
00117| Use :meth:`~Flask.shell_context_processor` to add other automatic imports.
00118| 
00119| 
00120| Environments
00121| ------------
00122| 
00123| .. versionadded:: 1.0
00124| 
00125| The environment in which the Flask app runs is set by the
00126| :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable. If not set it defaults to
00127| ``production``. The other recognized environment is ``development``.
00128| Flask and extensions may choose to enable behaviors based on the
00129| environment.
00130| 
00131| If the env is set to ``development``, the ``flask`` command will enable
00132| debug mode and ``flask run`` will enable the interactive debugger and
00133| reloader.
00134| 
00135| ::
00136| 
00137|     $ FLASK_ENV=development flask run
00138|      * Serving Flask app "hello"
00139|      * Environment: development
00140|      * Debug mode: on
00141|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/ (Press CTRL+C to quit)
00142|      * Restarting with inotify reloader
00143|      * Debugger is active!
00144|      * Debugger PIN: 223-456-919
00145| 
00146| 
00147| Debug Mode
00148| ----------
00149| 
00150| Debug mode will be enabled when :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` is ``development``,
00151| as described above. If you want to control debug mode separately, use
00152| :envvar:`FLASK_DEBUG`. The value ``1`` enables it, ``0`` disables it.
00153| 
00154| 
00155| .. _dotenv:
00156| 
00157| Environment Variables From dotenv
00158| ---------------------------------
00159| 
00160| Rather than setting ``FLASK_APP`` each time you open a new terminal, you can
00161| use Flask's dotenv support to set environment variables automatically.
00162| 
00163| If `python-dotenv`_ is installed, running the ``flask`` command will set
00164| environment variables defined in the files :file:`.env` and :file:`.flaskenv`.
00165| This can be used to avoid having to set ``FLASK_APP`` manually every time you
00166| open a new terminal, and to set configuration using environment variables
00167| similar to how some deployment services work.
00168| 
00169| Variables set on the command line are used over those set in :file:`.env`,
00170| which are used over those set in :file:`.flaskenv`. :file:`.flaskenv` should be
00171| used for public variables, such as ``FLASK_APP``, while :file:`.env` should not
00172| be committed to your repository so that it can set private variables.
00173| 
00174| Directories are scanned upwards from the directory you call ``flask``
00175| from to locate the files. The current working directory will be set to the
00176| location of the file, with the assumption that that is the top level project
00177| directory.
00178| 
00179| The files are only loaded by the ``flask`` command or calling
00180| :meth:`~Flask.run`. If you would like to load these files when running in
00181| production, you should call :func:`~cli.load_dotenv` manually.
00182| 
00183| .. _python-dotenv: https://github.com/theskumar/python-dotenv#readme
00184| 
00185| 
00186| Environment Variables From virtualenv
00187| -------------------------------------
00188| 
00189| If you do not want to install dotenv support, you can still set environment
00190| variables by adding them to the end of the virtualenv's :file:`activate`
00191| script. Activating the virtualenv will set the variables.
00192| 
00193| Unix Bash, :file:`venv/bin/activate`::
00194| 
00195|     export FLASK_APP=hello
00196| 
00197| Windows CMD, :file:`venv\\Scripts\\activate.bat`::
00198| 
00199|     set FLASK_APP=hello
00200| 
00201| It is preferred to use dotenv support over this, since :file:`.flaskenv` can be
00202| committed to the repository so that it works automatically wherever the project
00203| is checked out.
00204| 
00205| 
00206| Custom Commands
00207| ---------------
00208| 
00209| The ``flask`` command is implemented using `Click`_. See that project's
00210| documentation for full information about writing commands.
00211| 
00212| This example adds the command ``create_user`` that takes the argument
00213| ``name``. ::
00214| 
00215|     import click
00216|     from flask import Flask
00217| 
00218|     app = Flask(__name__)
00219| 
00220|     @app.cli.command()
00221|     @click.argument('name')

00002| 
00003| Development Server
00004| ==================
00005| 
00006| .. currentmodule:: flask
00007| 
00008| Starting with Flask 0.11 there are multiple built-in ways to run a
00009| development server.  The best one is the :command:`flask` command line utility
00010| but you can also continue using the :meth:`Flask.run` method.
00011| 
00012| Command Line
00013| ------------
00014| 
00015| The :command:`flask` command line script (:ref:`cli`) is strongly
00016| recommended for development because it provides a superior reload
00017| experience due to how it loads the application.  The basic usage is like
00018| this::
00019| 
00020|     $ export FLASK_APP=my_application
00021|     $ export FLASK_ENV=development
00022|     $ flask run
00023| 
00024| This enables the development environment, including the interactive
00025| debugger and reloader, and then starts the server on
00026| *http://localhost:5000/*.
00027| 
00028| The individual features of the server can be controlled by passing more
00029| arguments to the ``run`` option. For instance the reloader can be
00030| disabled::
00031| 
00032|     $ flask run --no-reload
00033| 
00034| .. note::
00035| 
00036|     Prior to Flask 1.0 the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable was
00037|     not supported and you needed to enable debug mode by exporting
00038|     ``FLASK_DEBUG=1``. This can still be used to control debug mode, but
00039|     you should prefer setting the development environment as shown
00040|     above.
00041| 
00042| In Code
00043| -------
00044| 
00045| The alternative way to start the application is through the
00046| :meth:`Flask.run` method.  This will immediately launch a local server
00047| exactly the same way the :command:`flask` script does.
00048| 
00049| Example::
00050| 
00051|     if __name__ == '__main__':
00052|         app.run()
00053| 
00054| This works well for the common case but it does not work well for
00055| development which is why from Flask 0.11 onwards the :command:`flask`
00056| method is recommended.  The reason for this is that due to how the reload
00057| mechanism works there are some bizarre side-effects (like executing
00058| certain code twice, sometimes crashing without message or dying when a
00059| syntax or import error happens).
00060| 
00061| It is however still a perfectly valid method for invoking a non automatic
00062| reloading application.
00063|

Development Server
==================

.. currentmodule:: flask

Starting with Flask 0.11 there are multiple built-in ways to run a
development server.  The best one is the :command:`flask` command line utility
but you can also continue using the :meth:`Flask.run` method.

Command Line
------------

The :command:`flask` command line script (:ref:`cli`) is strongly
recommended for development because it provides a superior reload
experience due to how it loads the application.  The basic usage is like
this::

00002| 
00003| Configuration Handling
00004| ======================
00005| 
00006| Applications need some kind of configuration.  There are different settings
00007| you might want to change depending on the application environment like
00008| toggling the debug mode, setting the secret key, and other such
00009| environment-specific things.
00010| 
00011| The way Flask is designed usually requires the configuration to be
00012| available when the application starts up.  You can hardcode the
00013| configuration in the code, which for many small applications is not
00014| actually that bad, but there are better ways.
00015| 
00016| Independent of how you load your config, there is a config object
00017| available which holds the loaded configuration values:
00018| The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` attribute of the :class:`~flask.Flask`
00019| object.  This is the place where Flask itself puts certain configuration
00020| values and also where extensions can put their configuration values.  But
00021| this is also where you can have your own configuration.
00022| 
00023| 
00024| Configuration Basics
00025| --------------------
00026| 
00027| The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` is actually a subclass of a dictionary and
00028| can be modified just like any dictionary::
00029| 
00030|     app = Flask(__name__)
00031|     app.config['TESTING'] = True
00032| 
00033| Certain configuration values are also forwarded to the
00034| :attr:`~flask.Flask` object so you can read and write them from there::
00035| 
00036|     app.testing = True
00037| 
00038| To update multiple keys at once you can use the :meth:`dict.update`
00039| method::
00040| 
00041|     app.config.update(
00042|         TESTING=True,
00043|         SECRET_KEY=b'_5#y2L"F4Q8z\n\xec]/'
00044|     )
00045| 
00046| 
00047| Environment and Debug Features
00048| ------------------------------
00049| 
00050| The :data:`ENV` and :data:`DEBUG` config values are special because they
00051| may behave inconsistently if changed after the app has begun setting up.
00052| In order to set the environment and debug mode reliably, Flask uses
00053| environment variables.
00054| 
00055| The environment is used to indicate to Flask, extensions, and other
00056| programs, like Sentry, what context Flask is running in. It is
00057| controlled with the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable and
00058| defaults to ``production``.
00059| 
00060| Setting :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` to ``development`` will enable debug mode.
00061| ``flask run`` will use the interactive debugger and reloader by default
00062| in debug mode. To control this separately from the environment, use the
00063| :envvar:`FLASK_DEBUG` flag.
00064| 
00065| .. versionchanged:: 1.0
00066|     Added :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` to control the environment separately
00067|     from debug mode. The development environment enables debug mode.
00068| 
00069| To switch Flask to the development environment and enable debug mode,
00070| set :envvar:`FLASK_ENV`::
00071| 
00072|     $ export FLASK_ENV=development
00073|     $ flask run
00074| 
00075| (On Windows, use ``set`` instead of ``export``.)
00076| 
00077| Using the environment variables as described above is recommended. While
00078| it is possible to set :data:`ENV` and :data:`DEBUG` in your config or
00079| code, this is strongly discouraged. They can't be read early by the
00080| ``flask`` command, and some systems or extensions may have already
00081| configured themselves based on a previous value.
00082| 
00083| 
00084| Builtin Configuration Values
00085| ----------------------------
00086| 
00087| The following configuration values are used internally by Flask:
00088| 
00089| .. py:data:: ENV
00090| 
00091|     What environment the app is running in. Flask and extensions may
00092|     enable behaviors based on the environment, such as enabling debug
00093|     mode. The :attr:`~flask.Flask.env` attribute maps to this config
00094|     key. This is set by the :envvar:`FLASK_ENV` environment variable and
00095|     may not behave as expected if set in code.
00096| 
00097|     **Do not enable development when deploying in production.**
00098| 
00099|     Default: ``'production'``
00100| 
00101|     .. versionadded:: 1.0
00102| 
00103| .. py:data:: DEBUG
00104| 
00105|     Whether debug mode is enabled. When using ``flask run`` to start the
00106|     development server, an interactive debugger will be shown for
00107|     unhandled exceptions, and the server will be reloaded when code
00108|     changes. The :attr:`~flask.Flask.debug` attribute maps to this
00109|     config key. This is enabled when :data:`ENV` is ``'development'``
00110|     and is overridden by the ``FLASK_DEBUG`` environment variable. It
00111|     may not behave as expected if set in code.
00112| 
00113|     **Do not enable debug mode when deploying in production.**
00114| 
00115|     Default: ``True`` if :data:`ENV` is ``'production'``, or ``False``
00116|     otherwise.
00117| 
00118| .. py:data:: TESTING
00119| 
00120|     Enable testing mode. Exceptions are propagated rather than handled by the
00121|     the app's error handlers. Extensions may also change their behavior to
00122|     facilitate easier testing. You should enable this in your own tests.
00123| 
00124|     Default: ``False``
00125| 
00126| .. py:data:: PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS
00127| 
00128|     Exceptions are re-raised rather than being handled by the app's error
00129|     handlers. If not set, this is implicitly true if ``TESTING`` or ``DEBUG``
00130|     is enabled.
00131| 
00132|     Default: ``None``
00133| 
00134| .. py:data:: PRESERVE_CONTEXT_ON_EXCEPTION
00135| 
00136|     Don't pop the request context when an exception occurs. If not set, this
00137|     is true if ``DEBUG`` is true. This allows debuggers to introspect the
00138|     request data on errors, and should normally not need to be set directly.
00139| 
00140|     Default: ``None``
00141|

Configuration Handling
======================

Applications need some kind of configuration.  There are different settings
you might want to change depending on the application environment like
toggling the debug mode, setting the secret key, and other such
environment-specific things.

The way Flask is designed usually requires the configuration to be
available when the application starts up.  You can hardcode the
configuration in the code, which for many small applications is not
actually that bad, but there are better ways.

Independent of how you load your config, there is a config object
available which holds the loaded configuration values:
The :attr:`~flask.Flask.config` attribute of the :class:`~flask.Flask`
object.  This is the place where Flask itself puts certain configuration
values and also where extensions can put their configuration values.  But
this is also where you can have your own configuration.","truncated":true},"time":{"start":1770024365687,"end":1770024365705}}}}

00002| 
00003| Quickstart
00004| ==========
00005| 
00006| Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
00007| assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
00008| :ref:`installation` section.
00009| 
00010| 
00011| A Minimal Application
00012| ---------------------
00013| 
00014| A minimal Flask application looks something like this::
00015| 
00016|     from flask import Flask
00017|     app = Flask(__name__)
00018| 
00019|     @app.route('/')
00020|     def hello_world():
00021|         return 'Hello, World!'
00022| 
00023| So what did that code do?
00024| 
00025| 1. First we imported the :class:`~flask.Flask` class.  An instance of this
00026|    class will be our WSGI application.
00027| 2. Next we create an instance of this class. The first argument is the name of
00028|    the application's module or package.  If you are using a single module (as
00029|    in this example), you should use ``__name__`` because depending on if it's
00030|    started as application or imported as module the name will be different
00031|    (``'__main__'`` versus the actual import name). This is needed so that
00032|    Flask knows where to look for templates, static files, and so on. For more
00033|    information have a look at the :class:`~flask.Flask` documentation.
00034| 3. We then use the :meth:`~flask.Flask.route` decorator to tell Flask what URL
00035|    should trigger our function.
00036| 4. The function is given a name which is also used to generate URLs for that
00037|    particular function, and returns the message we want to display in the
00038|    user's browser.
00039| 
00040| Just save it as :file:`hello.py` or something similar. Make sure to not call
00041| your application :file:`flask.py` because this would conflict with Flask
00042| itself.
00043| 
00044| To run the application you can either use the :command:`flask` command or
00045| python's ``-m`` switch with Flask.  Before you can do that you need
00046| to tell your terminal the application to work with by exporting the
00047| ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable::
00048| 
00049|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00050|     $ flask run
00051|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00052| 
00053| If you are on Windows, the environment variable syntax depends on command line
00054| interpreter. On Command Prompt::
00055| 
00056|     C:\path\to\app>set FLASK_APP=hello.py
00057| 
00058| And on PowerShell::
00059| 
00060|     PS C:\path\to\app> $env:FLASK_APP = "hello.py"
00061| 
00062| Alternatively you can use :command:`python -m flask`::
00063| 
00064|     $ export FLASK_APP=hello.py
00065|     $ python -m flask run
00066|      * Running on http://127.0.0.1:5000/
00067| 
00068| This launches a very simple builtin server, which is good enough for testing
00069| but probably not what you want to use in production. For deployment options see
00070| :ref:`deployment`.
00071| 
00072| Now head over to `http://127.0.0.1:5000/ <http://127.0.0.1:5000/>`_, and you
00073| should see your hello world greeting.
00074| 
00075| .. _public-server:
00076| 
00077| .. admonition:: Externally Visible Server
00078| 
00079|    If you run the server you will notice that the server is only accessible
00080|    from your own computer, not from any other in the network.  This is the
00081|    default because in debugging mode a user of the application can execute
00082|    arbitrary Python code on your computer.
00083| 
00084|    If you have the debugger disabled or trust the users on your network,
00085|    you can make the server publicly available simply by adding
00086|    ``--host=0.0.0.0`` to the command line::
00087| 
00088|        flask run --host=0.0.0.0
00089| 
00090|    This tells your operating system to listen on all public IPs.
00091| 
00092| 
00093| What to do if the Server does not Start
00094| ---------------------------------------
00095| 
00096| In case the :command:`python -m flask` fails or :command:`flask` does not exist,
00097| there are multiple reasons this might be the case.  First of all you need
00098| to look at the error message.
00099| 
00100| Old Version of Flask
00101| ````````````````````
00102| 
00103| Versions of Flask older than 0.11 use to have different ways to start the
00104| application.  In short, the :command:`flask` command did not exist, and
00105| neither did :command:`python -m flask`.  In that case you have two options:
00106| either upgrade to newer Flask versions or have a look at the :ref:`server`
00107| docs to see the alternative method for running a server.
00108| 
00109| Invalid Import Name
00110| ```````````````````
00111| 
00112| The ``FLASK_APP`` environment variable is the name of the module to import at
00113| :command:`flask run`. In case that module is incorrectly named you will get an
00114| import error upon start (or if debug is enabled when you navigate to the
00115| application). It will tell you what it tried to import and why it failed.
00116| 
00117| The most common reason is a typo or because you did not actually create an
00118| ``app`` object.
00119| 
00120| .. _debug-mode:
00121| 
00122| Debug Mode
00123| ----------
00124| 
00125| (Want to just log errors and stack traces? See :ref:`application-errors`)
00126| 
00127| The :command:`flask` script is nice to start a local development server, but
00128| you would have to restart it manually after each change to your code.
00129| That is not very nice and Flask can do better.  If you enable debug
00130| support the server will reload itself on code changes, and it will also
00131| provide you with a helpful debugger if things go wrong.
00132| 
00133| To enable all development features (including debug mode) you can export
00134| the ``FLASK_ENV`` environment variable and set it to ``development``
00135| before running the server::
00136| 
00137|     $ export FLASK_ENV=development
00138|     $ flask run
00139| 
00140| (On Windows you need to use ``set`` instead of ``export``.)
00141| 
00142| This does the following things:
00143| 
00144| 1.  it activates the debugger
00145| 2.  it activates the automatic reloader
00146| 3.  it enables the debug mode on the Flask application.
00147| 
00148| You can also control debug mode separately from the environment by
00149| exporting ``FLASK_DEBUG=1``.
00150| 
00151| There are more parameters that are explained in the :ref:`server` docs.
00152| 
00153| .. admonition:: Attention
00154|

Quickstart
==========

Eager to get started?  This page gives a good introduction to Flask.  It
assumes you already have Flask installed.  If you do not, head over to the
:ref:`installation` section.


A Minimal Application
---------------------

A minimal Flask application looks something like this::

    from flask import Flask
    app = Flask(__name__)

    @app.route('/')
    def hello_world():
